title: Thursday, 1st March, 2018
bodyHTML:
DerivedCategory Morning all.
Deep Breath everyone... Morning
11:05 am
BE11:06am

Hi. Good morning. Hello. Welcome to March, and also to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily etc.

BE11:06am

Cold, innit?

DerivedCategory Fun train ride back from Glasgow last night...
BE11:06am

Anyway, have a picture.

GBKrona Hola - yes, freezing
Grouchmonkey Bit of a late start Car 67?
11:06 am
BE11:06am

DerivedCategory Delayed by icicles on the overhead wires
Waterloo Can we have tin hats with a lining please.
Grouchmonkey Carpetright warning - I'm shocked, shocked.
Soundbuy Morgen
BE11:07am

That's a page from "STARTUP LONDON", from the pretty excellent wee publisher Hoxton Mini Press.

BE11:07am

Available to you for just .... wait, what?

A. M. Morning. Is that Rohan Silva, ElReg's BFF?
11:07 am
BE11:07am

https://www.hoxton...cts/startup-london

BE11:07am

£28!

Pseudonym Can we not do WPP it's just too depressing?
#REF! @DerivedCategory was that the train that was taking on snow? https://twitter.com/marybduffy/status/968763507570348032?s=20 (BE I can't remember rules on external links, apologies if you have to delete this)
Blue horseshoe... Shire?
BE11:08am

Hoxton Mini Press stuff tends to be £15 a pop. But I guess the people in this one are willing to pay a premium to see their delightful pre-Unicorn visages in print.

Grouchmonkey If we are avoiding WPP can we do CRH results instead, please?
11:08 am
BE11:09am

Yearbook strategy.

DerivedCategory @REF not that train, but it was also taking on snow. No one made a snowman though.
OnYourRight Morning all
Kiwi-juice comment on Hastings please
BE11:09am

Anyway, it looks delightful and not just for reasons that you get to see Rohan Silva doing whatever Rohan Silva does.

undefined
Nately Ahoy. Finally in.
11:09 am
BE11:10am

Okay ........ we have results. We have so many results!

Forester I have picked up some WPP - madness I know!
BE11:11am

We'll try and cover everything, but, inevitably, won't. So don't get antsy over there please.

BE11:11am

Get WPP out of the way first, I figure, even though it's covered in depth elsewhere.

OnYourRight @Forester I did the same but only a spreadbet I'm afraid.
11:11 am
BE11:12am

The guidance isn't all that different from previous. As in, 2018 will be dead money. No sales growth and no margin improvement.

BE11:12am

Sorrell had already said that.

Waterloo So will we go to war with Holland over gas? Just cray we have so little/no storage.
Forester Kinda think that the "death of advertising" is a tad premature....just new ways to achieve the same end
BE11:12am

The problems are Q4 and January.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Which are awful.

DerivedCategory Apparently the trains that run best in the snow are those old lean-out-the-window-to-open-the-door british rail ones. It's just unfortunate they aren't very weather tight.
BE11:13am

Morgan Stanley has a summary which is better than any I can type in a hurry. Here we are.

Waterloo In place of those old storage tanks are £1m apartments no one can sell
Mark Shapland what's going with Aveva shares this morning?
BE11:13am

Poor Q4: WPP did -0.9% organic net sales growth for 2017 (versus our -0.4% ) implying a worse than expected -1.3% in Q4 (MSe 0.4%). There is a 1.5% miss at the EBIT level but the margin was in line with expectations down 10bps at 17.3%. The net eps outturn was in line at 120.4p
Weak guidance: WPP is guiding to organic flat net sales growth in 2018 and a flat underlying margin in constant currency. We have 0.5% organic net sales growth and a 10 bps margin improvement. WPP says it is guiding conservatively but this is still likely to put pressure on forecasts.
January net sales growth is down 1.2% although this is against a relatively tough comp ( 1.2% in Jan 17 was the strongest month of the year!)
WPP has reduced its medium term guidance targets: WPP used to guide in its medium term business model to 10-15% growth pa. This has been reduced to medium term growth of 5-10%.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

New restructuring provision of 57m. This is taken in the Q4 2017 numbers and is new.
Net debt at the year-end was 4.48bn . The average net debt/EBITDA is 2.0x , right
at the top of WPP’s comfort range of 1.5x-2.0x
US net sales were down 3.4% in Q4 ,so little sign of revival there.
Net new business was a relatively healthy $6.33bn. Expect WPP to be asked about the Ford relationship at the 9.30am meeting Consensus forecasts likely to be under pressure by c3-4%. Consensus has already moved down in 2018 from c122p of eps to c119p on currency and is likely to fall further today with perhaps another c3-4p downgrade to c115p

OnYourRight @Waterloo 1m+ flats that look like every other 1m+ flat.
h1 Carpetright going down down down
BE11:15am

So ........ not huge downgrades. But hugely disappointing as we try to separate out the winners and the losers in the world where ad companies are beginning to look more like Accenture than Bartle Bogle Hegarty.

A. M. @Waterloo -- that was town-gas, surely. What can be said? Centrica picked a good time to stop maintenance in Rough.
BE11:16am

Citi .....

deepdiscount @Mark Shapland now combined with Schneider Electric. Return of capital to shareholders.
Lemmy Shapland: the deal with Schneider
11:16 am
BE11:16am

There is no escaping it: the 4Q is weaker than expected and weaker than some of the group’s main peers. In terms of the main culprit it is clear this is largely a function of poor trading on the traditional side of the business (advertising and media buying was -2.3% for the FY vs. -1.2% forecast implying -3.7% in the 4Q). If the weak 4Q performance wasn’t bad enough, the group’s initial guide on FY18E is also perhaps weaker than investors might have hoped in light of positive commentary from peers. For the FY the group is guiding for flat growth and flat margins (not necessarily different from previous commentary) but January net sales down -1.2% - even if it is ahead of budget – is hardly an auspicious start.

Mark Shapland oh
Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous people
BE11:17am

Margin Slightly Weaker Too — Previous margin guidance had been for flat progression YoY but ended up down 10bps to 17.3%. In part this is explained by FX but also the weaker end to the year must have had a part to play. Flat margin guidance for 2018E is at first glance helpful but against the backdrop of a lower 2017A it implies downside for citi/consensus (17.7%/17.5%)

OnYourRight Is Powell going to say anything goundbreaking this afternoon?
Forester Bartle Bogle Hegarty - those were the days! Golf GTIs, red rimmed specs, running ideas up flagpoles.....if only everything in life is as reliable as an ad agency!
BE11:17am

From an operational forecast perspective the lower base from 2017 and the flat growth/flat margin guidance would imply c. -3% off consensus estimates. FX pressures have reversed somewhat but we would still anticipate consensus EPS downgrades in the 3%-5% range.

Waterloo No kidding. If the weather was much worse for longer, UK industry would be back to the future on a 3 day week. So much for critical infrastructure. Maybe we could turn some of the out of town stores into gas storage?
Pseudonym Prevailing westerly will win out in the end.
red sticking to my opinion with wpp its structural, despite the cries from within to the contrary
Phil WPP being squeezed by Google + Facebook?
A. M. @Waterloo: http://www.gie.eu/index.php/maps-data < for all your infrastructure needs
OnYourRight @Waterloo Would that be "Shops R Gas"?!?!?
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Hey, quick question. Where was Sorrell yesterday evening?

red @Philimo yes. we not only my opinion, i dare say a fair few others too
BE11:19am

That'd be an interesting question for City diarists to ask.

BE11:19am

Anyway. Let's push on.

11:19 am
undefined
Phil red: indeed. Industry has shifted. A friend recently jumped ship from a WPP subsidiary to Google because that’s where the interesting work is.
erlkin onyouright...i think powell will attempt to balance his commentary and markets will likely rebound a tad...mnunchin was recently quoted as saying the correction was healthy so don't look for too much....Gold has been taken to the woodshed...i'm looking for a pop...
BE11:20am

Okay, still on results .....

RAVER Good shout @Dec69 ITV was an indicator for WPP
JimboRock legerdemain for Merlin
Gross Loydman Petrofac please
h1 Carpetright ;D
VV75 I second Petrofac
BE11:21am

What was requested? Hastings? Sure, we can do Hastings. Quickly though because it's kinda dull.

11:21 am
PM11:21am

Hi

Waterloo erlkin, funny that I suspect the S&P will test the recent lows. Poor PMI's, poor home sales, rates on the rise
Hastings Group Holdings PLC (HSTG:LSE): Last: 285.80, down 26.8 (-8.57%), High: 313.60, Low: 280.00, Volume: 1.30m
BE11:22am

Oh, hello Paul.

Lemmy Cryptic on Sorrell BE
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Right, so car insurance. Hastings is a policy writing slowdown and a huge run-up ahead of the figures.

BE11:22am

As Barclays can explain.

PM11:23am

Go on

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Hastings has been the best performing motor stock since January 2017, rallying over 23% and outperforming the European sector growth of 8.5%. We believe this is justified as it continues to deliver on both its IPO promises and revised 2019 targets. The company delivered 12% policy growth, 21% increase in premiums, 39% increase in operating profit and 27% increase in the dividend. All metrics were broadly in line with our and company-compiled consensus estimates, and against a less favorable trading environment towards the end of the year, with no reliance on reserve releases. There have been indications in H217 that the cycle is slowing – and Hastings’ policy growth slowed from 8% in H1, when it benefited from increased shopping due to the surprise Ogden change, to 4% in H2 as the government indicated it would reverse some of the Ogden impact. We view the slowdown in growth as evidence of Hastings’ rhetoric to not grow at the expense of profitability.

OnYourRight @Erlkin@Waterloo I'm looking for a leg lower......
erlkin waterloo....you may have noticed the ten year yield faded towards the end of the day....i suspect he will borrow a page from Yellen and talk gradual.....mkts will bounce back is my guess...
Mouselet Phil: Google is strikingly opaque, though maybe within the ad industry it's a bit clearer what you would get to do there
BE11:23am

Premiums up 21% YoY missed consensus whigh was for about 24%.

BE11:24am

So, shares down. That's that.

undefined

G/F have all the interesting data to delve into & find new and interesting ways to sell people things & WPP et al have been left out in the cold scratching at the window pane.

red @erlkin2682 on s&p. below there a lower low and along with bearish candle, it wont look good. week is a long time and plenty of swing within that so not all bad news if bull, but pressure would be on downside until techincally better pic.

Well, Petrofac's an interesting company in terms of revenue recognition on long-term contracts

The order intake and backlog numbers are consistently pretty impressive, as they often are with engineering services businesses.

Mouselet you still need the creatives to make the adverts, but I suppose that's all outsourced to small creative groups which then outsource again to get the cameras and the sets and the studios
BE11:29am

And I don't need to highlight that engineering services businesses have been in focus recently, albeit the UK public service types rather than the "building a gas processing plant in Oman" types.

Mouselet all that is solid melts into air
BE11:29am

Anyway, putting all that aside for a moment, the numbers look okay.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Here's JP Morgan to summarise.

Mouselet ... maybe I should try reading Capital again, but the axiom clash when he starts off with the principle that true prices exist really got me last time
BE11:30am

Petrofac delivered a good set of underlying results, despite an 11% revenue miss in 2H 17. PFC beat implied company derived 2H 17 EBITDA by 9% (+10% vs. JPMe), reporting 2H EBITDA of $407m and giving a margin of 12.5% (consensus 10.2%, JPMe 9.9%), helped by IES at the top of guidance range and strong execution in E&C. At the segment level; FY17 E&C net margin of 7.1% (7.5% 2H 17) remains inside the target range of 7-8%. Cash collections into the year-end were also strong with the company reporting net debt of $612m, significantly ahead of pre-close guidance of ~$850m. PFC continues to prioritize deleveraging and has formally committed to exit deep-water, classifying the JSD6000 as held for sale. A further impairment on GSA due to high gas oil ratio is something of a disappointment. Finally, we note that while no update on the SFO was given, CEO Ayman Asfari has had his board restrictions, in place since May 2017, lifted. PFC is well covered for 2018 (greater than 90%), but contract awards will continue to be the focus, particularly given the expected 2H bias for contract awards this year. Overall we see today’s results as another indication of continuing solid operations and remain OW.

BE11:30am

And SocGen. Also positive.

Forester @mouselet yeah that was my thought. You can have all the clever data you like but you still need clever ads to get out attention and open our wallets
11:30 am
BE11:31am

We reiterate our Buy rating following the just released stronger-than-expected 2017 results. We think the sharp greater than 50% drop in the share price following the 12 May announcement of a UK Serious Fraud Office investigation is excessive, even assuming a heavy fine (i.e. $320m as implied by Rolls Royce’s SFO fine) or an even steeper penalty (we have $640m built into our valuation). The group’s strong 1H17 results underpin our positive view; SFO aside, we think order intake is now likely to be the key share price driver.

Mouselet Well, it depends. "Second-hand 16-core Xeon E5-2650 server, 64G RAM, £520" got my attention and opened my wallet in as many words, no dancing bunny suits needed
BE11:31am

Numis also buyers.

BE11:31am

Valuation - BUY rating and 700p/sh price target. We think the operational headwinds faced by Petrofac have fallen since Q2 of last year. Our PT is in line with our DCF valuation (9% WACC), implying a target 2018 EV/EBITDA of 5.2x and 2018e PE of 9.6x - neither of which is demanding in an improving operational environment, in our view

Mouselet at the moment I am looking into buying a bassoon, and that's an utterly awful market because they are fairly artisanal products and I know that I don't have the competence to evaluate them

Mouselet I guess I have to believe that music shops are run by musical people, pick a budget, and go to a real shop and tootle on all available bassoons

BE11:34am

Flaneur (@ElecDrag - nice reference! )
Phil Mouselet / Forester: sure, but the creative side can simply go direct to clients themselves. I would expect that side of the industry to survive just fine, in all it’s Shoreditch glory.
11:40 am
BE11:41am

Here's Credit Suisse's ..... wait, I'll cut and paste this ..... Guillaume Gauvillé.

BE11:41am

This brings a possible LFL acceleration earlier than expected. In fact, having left Givenchy in February 2017, Tisci is no longer subject to the usual non-compete clause from LVMH. Therefore, him joining this month means that he will be able to present his debut collections at the September fashion show. We would expect Burberry to stick to the seasonless 'see now, buy now' fashion calendar but we believe the runway products will only account for a small portion of sales in 2H19. The Spring/Summer part of his collections will only be available in stores from April/May next year and, therefore, any impact on LFL could occur from 1H20.

BE11:42am

The announcement today perhaps represents the last missing part for the turnaround plan. [...] Burberry remains our favourite restructuring story in the luxury space. The company has gone through the biggest management reshuffle since IPO, margins are below the historical average and the impact from rationalisation of the off-price and wholesale channels, largely in the US, should be partly offset by a cost-cutting plan in place.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Aye, okay. And Jefferies thinks the opposite.

Mouselet Isn't the purpose of ad agencies to tell you which people in Shoreditch to go to? I'm not certain that any ditch would do
BE11:43am

BRBY is hardly Givenchy: it is a bigger and far more complex proposition as we suspect Gobbetti has already realized since joining from Celine.

BRBY has always made much of its 'Britishness' (even though the supply chain tells a rather different story). There were British names talked about (Philo, Jones) and we thought this would be a more likely route. Indeed, this shift away from tradition may prove challenging given it is integral to a deteriorating brand profile that we believe needs a refresh.

Conclusion: a mixed message: While we continue to argue that the appointment of a new Chief Creative Officer was a red herring given the size and complexities at BRBY, we view the choice of Tisci as quite peculiar. Yes he is talented and with a solid reputation, but this now means that three of the five key executives are Italian (Gobbetti, Bonesi and now Tisci), which we expect will be questioned by the market given BRBY's particular history: it worked at Saint Laurent, it may work here, but an unusual appointment nonetheless.

Pseudonym @Mouselet Mango Tango would make a great name for your baboon.

- He has also designed the stage outfits for world tours of Madonna, Beyoncé and Rihanna, introducing his aesthetic to an ever-widening audience.

We are not aware of any recent speculation around other interested parties in Laird. In 2011, there was bid for by Cooper Industries (185p, then raised to 200p but rebuffed by management). Cooper has been acquired by Eaton since then.
